body.p: This column is the second of three dedicated to sharing examples of applications (aka apps) and other resources for using technology to support quality early learning and development opportunities.

sec.title: Tots-n-Tech E-Newsletters
sec.p: Two recent newsletters from Tots-n-Tech focused on ways in which technology can support young learners. The April 2011 issue (The iPad: It’s Your Turn to Be Heard) focused on ways in which iPads can support social skills, play, communication, and scheduling for infants and toddlers. The March 2012 issue (More on the iPad) focused on integrating the iPad into existing activities and routines. Both issues identify no-cost and low-cost apps.

sec.title: The Best Free 22 Applications for Kids
sec.p: This website offers brief descriptions of free apps for young children (birth to age 8), sorted by chronological age.

sec.title: CAST UDL Book Builder
sec.p: Use this site to create, share, publish, and read digital books that engage and support diverse learners according to their individual needs, interests, and skills. Sample books are provided to help you envision the possibilities.

sec.title: UDL Tech Toolkit Wiki
sec.p: For learning tools—everything from text-to-speech, writing tools, and writing aids specifically designed for children with handwriting issues—this is a very useful site.

sec.title: Signed Stories
sec.p: To view stories told in sign language (with subtitles and an audio option) visit this website. The literary categories you’ll find include adventure, fairytales and folktales, slimy scary books, and funny stories.

sec.title: Put It Away
sec.p: Put It Away is a free iPad app that can create visual templates for teaching children how to clean up or organize (e.g., garbage belongs in the wastebasket). Customization enables family members and teachers to use this app to simulate the real places in which children spend time.

sec.title: ABA Receptive Identification
sec.p: This low-cost app is designed to teach foundational language concepts to early learners. The app offers more than 300 beautiful, concrete photos presented against a nondistracting white background. Every image has been carefully selected for its familiarity, appeal to children, and developmental value. Cost: US$1.99.

sec.title: I Create . . . Social Skills Stories
sec.p: I Create . . . Social Skills Stories can help families and professionals make unlimited personalized social skill storybooks by importing personal photos and adding titles, text, and audio to unlimited pages in the story. All the books can be rearranged in an order specific to daily routines. Storybooks offer visual and audio support to help individuals recall steps of a sequence and to build receptive and expressive vocabulary. Cost: US$4.99.
